Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2010 12:04PM LesleyLP wrote: Hi Patti, I'm also on Arimidex but imagine the side effects are pretty similar - had awful sinus problems for the first six months I was on these drugs - had nasal sprays etc from GP, then had a couple of Hopi Ear Candle treatments which helped quite a lot.  Fingers crossed, it all seems to have settled down now - hope it does the same for you  Like Lowrider, I can stand almost any amount of side effects if it means the drugs are doing the job!  My latest CA15-3 markers are down to 25 so I'm happy :)  xx

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2013 06:35AM LesleyLP wrote: Hi lukejessesmom - I haven't been to this site for ages and hardly ever post, but just had to let you know of my tumour marker experience (I have bone and liver mets)  In March 2012, Letrozole having failed me miserably, my CA15-3 was 6,487.  I've been on Xeloda ever since then - I know that's a different chemo to you - but they are now 35 and have been that low for a couple of months :o    So I guess what I'm trying to say is don't panic too much about the markers, I know it's very hard - but they can drop as fast as they rise and I hope that will be the case for you too.  Lesley xx

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2009 06:33PM - edited Sep 18, 2009 06:37PM by LesleyLP I'm trying to post a link on here from the UK - it's a video interview of a woman who is a 34 year mets survivor - but it won't let me post it for some reason.  Try Googling Sky News 34 year woman beating cancer - you should get a video of this amazing lady playing golf - she's had bc with liver and various other mets for 34 years - incredible!! I personally know a lady who lives near me who's been living with bc and lung mets for 12 years and is still doing well.  My oncologist has assured me she has several ladies who are doing well on 10 years plus.  I think there is a lot of hope out there ...

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2010 07:04AM LesleyLP wrote: Hi mags - are you on any hormonal drugs - Tamoxifen, Arimidex or Femara?  If so it's very probably those which are giving you the stiffness rather than the bone mets.  Stiff, aching joints are one of the main side effects of hormonal drugs. Lesley
